questions.question: She ....................... have gone to work but I am not sure.
questions.description: Can is only used to talk about theoretical possibility. In other cases, we use may to indicate possibility.

questions.question: ........................... I borrow your camera?
questions.description: Both can and may are used to ask for permission.

questions.question: ............................ you move a bit?
questions.description: In polite requests, we use can, not may.

questions.question: ...................... I come in teacher?
questions.description: Both can and may can be used to ask for permission.

questions.question: She .......................... read when she was just three.
questions.description: We use could to talk about past ability.

questions.question: It is impossible. They ............................. have lost their way.
You ....................... go after you have finished your work.
questions.description: May is considered more correct here but can is gaining acceptance.

questions.question: What ......................... you do if she doesn't recognize you?
questions.description: To express simple futurity, we use will.

questions.question: .............................. you translate this article into German?
questions.description: Both can and could are possible here could is used in a more polite style.

questions.question: Who ......................... it be?
questions.description: In questions we use can to express possibility.
